content: The Act may be cited as the "NASA Innovation Fund and Sponsorship Act of 2007". It includes a section on the NASA Innovation Fund. The "NASA Innovation Fund" is established in the Treasury of the United States, funded by charitable donations or program proceeds. The Fund can be used for advertising, limited to 10% of the total amount. The NASA Innovation Fund allows for expenditures on advertising and administration, with limits on the amounts that can be used for each purpose. The NASA Innovation Fund can be used by the Administrator for administering the prize competition and awarding prizes. The Fund can also be invested in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. Investments from the NASA Innovation Fund can only be made in interest-bearing obligations of the United States, which can be acquired on original issue or by purchase. The obligations held in the Fund can be sold at market price, with the interest and proceeds credited back to the Fund. The interest and proceeds from the sale or redemption of obligations in the Fund are credited back to the Fund. NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship Advisory Committee. The NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship Advisory Committee is established within NASA to advise on program implementation. The Advisory Committee consists of 5 US citizens with expertise in math or science education and promotional activities, appointed by the Administrator within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship Advisory Committee is established to advise on program implementation. The Committee consists of 5 US citizens with expertise in math or science education and promotional activities, appointed by the Administrator within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for staggered three-year terms. The NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship Advisory Committee consists of 5 US citizens with expertise in math or science education and promotional activities. Members serve staggered three-year terms. If a member departs before their term ends, a successor may be appointed to serve the remainder of the term. The Advisory Committee members serve staggered three-year terms and may be reappointed for up to 6 years. They are not compensated for their services but are reimbursed for necessary expenses. The Committee meets regularly. The Advisory Committee meets at least 4 times a year, with the option for additional meetings. The Administrator and Chief of Strategic Communications of NASA, or their representatives, must attend to provide guidance. SEC. 4. INNOVATION FUND SPONSORSHIP PROGRAM. The Administrator is authorized to create an Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program allowing individuals to use the Partnership Logo in exchange for a monetary contribution to the Fund. Participants approved for the program are known as sponsors. The Administrator will select and adopt a Partnership Logo. To participate in the Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program, individuals approved as sponsors must submit an application to the Administrator. The logo for sponsors will include the words "NASA Innovation Fund Partner" and an image chosen by the Advisory Committee. The Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program requires approved sponsors to submit an application to the Administrator, including the amount to be contributed and a description of the promotional program using the Partnership Logo. The Advisory Committee reviews proposals and makes recommendations to the Administrator. The Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program promotes educational programs and opportunities in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. Approved sponsors must enter into a sponsorship agreement with the Administrator. The Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program requires approved sponsors to enter into a sponsorship agreement with the Administrator. The agreement mandates sponsors to provide a specified amount and allows them to use the Partnership Logo in their promotional program, with restrictions on logos on spacecraft. Restrictions for promotional programs under the Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program include no logos on spacecraft, no astronaut endorsements, no agency-wide endorsements, and no in-kind contributions. The Administrator establishes restrictions for promotional programs under the Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program, including no logos on spacecraft, no astronaut or agency-wide endorsements, and no in-kind contributions. Additionally, procedures are set up to protect proprietary information submitted. The Administrator establishes procedures to protect proprietary information submitted. Congress encourages NASA to participate in activities authorized under the National Aeronautics and Space Act. The Administrator may take legal action against unauthorized use of the Partnership Logo in connection with promotions, with penalties imposed. The Administrator may impose a civil penalty of $100,000 for violations of unauthorized promotional programs using the Partnership Logo. Legal action, including injunctions, may be taken to prevent non-compliant promotional activities. Annual reports are required by October 31st. The Administrator can impose a $100,000 civil penalty for unauthorized use of the Partnership Logo. Legal action, such as injunctions, can be taken to stop non-compliant promotional activities. An annual report must be submitted to Congress by October 31 detailing NASA's actions, receipts, expenditures, and evaluating the Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program. The Advisory Committee must submit an annual report to Congress by October 31, including expenditures, evaluation of the Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program, and consultation with NASA Centers for program improvement ideas. NASA has ten research centers including Ames, Dryden, Glenn, Goddard, JPL, Johnson, Kennedy, Langley, Marshall, and Stennis. SEC. 5 of the National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958 is amended to include the NASA Innovation Fund and Sponsorship Act of 2007. SEC. 6 provides definitions.
